articles.headline: Justices’ Rulings Advance Gays; Women Less So
articles.snippet: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said the court’s conservative majority, all men, did not understand the challenges women face in achieving authentic equality.
articles.abstract: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said the court’s conservative majority, all men, did not understand the challenges women face in achieving authentic equality.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg reflects on the Supreme Court’s recent rulings, she sees an inconsistency.

articles.headline: Time Warner Rebuff of Fox May Not Just Be Negotiating Ploy
articles.snippet: With Time Warner Inc.’s rejection last month of an $80 billion bid by Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox, the mating ritual had begun, or so it seemed.
articles.abstract: With Time Warner Inc.’s rejection last month of an $80 billion bid by Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox, the mating ritual had begun, or so it seemed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch tends to finish what he starts. So from the moment the news broke last month that Time Warner Inc. had rejected an $80 billion bid by Mr. Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox, the assumption on Wall Street and in the media world was that it was only a matter of time before a deal was struck.

articles.headline: Taking a Bullet, Gaining a Cause: James S. Brady Dies at 73
articles.snippet: Mr. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan, championed tighter regulations from his wheelchair.
articles.abstract: Mr. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan, championed tighter regulations from his wheelchair.
articles.lead_paragraph: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan and then became a symbol of the fight for gun control, championing tighter regulations from his wheelchair, died on Monday in Alexandria, Va. He was 73.

articles.headline: Reagan Book Sets Off Debate
articles.snippet: Rick Perlstein’s “The Invisible Bridge” has been accused of sloppy scholarship, improper attribution and plagiarism.
articles.abstract: Rick Perlstein’s “The Invisible Bridge” has been accused of sloppy scholarship, improper attribution and plagiarism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rick Perlstein always hoped his book on the rise of Ronald Reagan would set off serious debate among scholars and historians. Just not this debate.

articles.headline: Banco Espírito Santo Patriarch Humbled Amid Bailout
articles.snippet: The family of Ricardo Espírito Santo Silva Salgado controlled the bank for nearly a century. Now prosecutors and regulators are investigating possible accounting fraud.
articles.abstract: The family of Ricardo Espírito Santo Silva Salgado controlled the bank for nearly a century. Now prosecutors and regulators are investigating possible accounting fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2011, just before entering into bailout discussions with creditors, Portugal’s prime minister put in a call to consult with the country’s most powerful banker, Ricardo Espírito Santo Silva Salgado.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Raphael Minder

articles.headline: Ackman and Valeant’s Bid for Botox Maker May Be Too Clever to Be Legal
articles.snippet: A lawsuit by Allergan says the unusual arrangement by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and William A. Ackman amounts to insider trading, and the judge’s decision will rest upon a set of arcane financial rules.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit by Allergan says the unusual arrangement by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and William A. Ackman amounts to insider trading, and the judge’s decision will rest upon a set of arcane financial rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tiptoeing on a tightrope past insider trading laws may be deft and clever, but it doesn’t make it right.

articles.headline: Focusing on G.M. Unit, U.S. Starts Civil Inquiry of Subprime Car Lending
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors have begun a civil investigation of the subprime auto lending practices of General Motors and other companies, focusing on the packaging and selling of questionable loans to investors.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors have begun a civil investigation of the subprime auto lending practices of General Motors and other companies, focusing on the packaging and selling of questionable loans to investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have begun a civil investigation into the booming business of subprime auto lending, focusing on the packaging and selling of questionable loans to investors.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Buildup Makes Russia Battle-Ready for Ukraine
articles.snippet: Adding battalions near the border with Ukraine could allow Russia to launch a cross-border incursion there with little or no warning, Western officials said.
articles.abstract: Adding battalions near the border with Ukraine could allow Russia to launch a cross-border incursion there with little or no warning, Western officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has roughly doubled the number of its battalions near the Ukrainian border, Western officials said Monday, and could respond to the Kiev government’s gains there by launching a cross-border incursion with little or no warning.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Lax Quarantine Undercuts Ebola Fight in Africa
articles.snippet: Sierra Leone, the nation with the most cases of the disease, has banned many public gatherings and set strict quarantine rules, but health officials are deeply worried by loose enforcement efforts.
articles.abstract: Sierra Leone, the nation with the most cases of the disease, has banned many public gatherings and set strict quarantine rules, but health officials are deeply worried by loose enforcement efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — The house was supposed to be under strict quarantine. Meals were to be delivered by the health department. Nobody was to go in or out.

articles.headline: Gaza War Strains Relations Between U.S. and Israel
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government has largely dismissed American efforts to end the violence, leaving U.S. officials to seethe on the sidelines.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government has largely dismissed American efforts to end the violence, leaving U.S. officials to seethe on the sidelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the State Department condemned Israel’s strike on a United Nations school in Gaza on Sunday, saying it was “appalled” by this “disgraceful” act, it gave full vent to what has been weeks of mounting American anger toward the Israeli government.

articles.headline: Israel Exits Gaza as Truce Begins
articles.snippet: As a 72-hour truce mediated by Egypt took hold, Israel said it had withdrawn its forces from Gaza and Hamas said it would engage in talks on a lasting peace arrangement.
articles.abstract: As a 72-hour truce mediated by Egypt took hold, Israel said it had withdrawn its forces from Gaza and Hamas said it would engage in talks on a lasting peace arrangement.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As a 72-hour cease-fire mediated by Egypt took hold on Tuesday, Gazans emerged to view a shattered landscape with Hamas still in power, while Israel began to debate the politics, costs and accomplishments of the monthlong war.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: U.S. General Is Killed in Attack at Afghan Base; Others Injured
articles.snippet: An Afghan soldier killed Maj. Gen. Harold J. Greene, who appeared to be the highest-ranking member of the American military to die in hostilities overseas since the Vietnam War.
articles.abstract: An Afghan soldier killed Maj. Gen. Harold J. Greene, who appeared to be the highest-ranking member of the American military to die in hostilities overseas since the Vietnam War.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the first time since Vietnam, a United States Army general was killed in an overseas conflict on Tuesday when an Afghan soldier opened fire on senior American officers at a military training academy.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Helene Cooper
